remixed_from.title: GoPro customizable mounts, and a library to expand

description.text: This item is deprecated, use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:623414 instead. Seat post mount for 27.2 seat posts and GoPro compatible mounts. Extension arm is long enough to mount a Contour or other bullet style camera above the arm. Wanted to make sure this was stiff enough, modified some of the clamp widths. Loosely based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62800 Files are provided in multiple formats for those that want to tinker with them.

Created two parts using the following Customizer http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=62800, first was a clamp. Use any head you want for the primary as I discarded it. Then created a second extension arm with triple head longer than needed. Converted all pieces from meshes (.stl) to solid objects in FreeCAD. Cut off head from clamp at an 8.5° angle, and cut off the arm at 8.5° to desired length. Combined both pieces together and ran it through the Microsoft netfabb online repair tool https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ . This extension arm is a bit longer than the original to accommodate bullet style cameras mounted above the arm, such as the Contour Roam, etc. Use two 3 mm x 15 mm cap screws and two 3 mm nylock nuts to secure clamp on seat post.

Simple bolt hobbing jig that clamps in your vice on a mill or tool post in a lathe.   Uses 2 bearing to allow the bolt to feely rotate. Also has a hole through the clamp block so you can see the hobbing depth unimpeded by the tap.  
If you want a diffenent sized clamping part let me know and I'll upload another size.

required parts to finish are:
-2 x 608zz bearings
-2 x M3x25mm cap head screws
-2 x M3 nuts I print so the layers are horizontal through the jib. the M3 cap screws ensure that layers cannot delaminate with the insalled bearings. I use an M5 3 flute gun nose tap when hobbing. Once the tap touches the bolt I cut to a depth of 1mm. This give a nice radius for the bolt to grab the filament and nice sharp teeth.
This mounts my older Bose speakers on to my hearth.  It just clips on to the mantle (no nails or screws), and uses the mount bolt on the back of the speaker.

Make it fit your mantle by adjusting these parameters:
mantleHeight: Top-to-bottom measurement
mantleLip: positions the clip on the bottom part of the clamp so it clicks around the overhang on the bottom.

title: PrintrBot Simple Metal Chassis 60mm Fan Mount

description.text:
Just a simple set of mounts designed to fit underneath my PrintrBot Simple Metal, to allow fans to be mounted to cool the Z/X motors and stepper drivers on the main-board.  
UPDATE 09/01/2015: I found that the friction fit was a bit too ambitious, and the mounts popped out during printing. Version 1.1 (60mm PBSM Fan Holder 1.1-vented-dualhole.stl) corrects this by removing 2mm from the mount body, making it a perfect fit for the PBSM. This does mean a drop of hot glue is required to keep it in place, but at least it won't pop out now!

This mounts are designed to sit the fans within the chassis, but only at an 8mm depth - this is deliberate to give more space between the motors and the fan to maximize airflow, and also to allow as much clearance as possible for the wiring loom. I have some low profile fans (only 10mm depth on a 60mm fan) on order, and they will sit more or less flush with the bottom of the printer once fitted. The ones shown in the pictures are standard 60mm fans, and have an overall depth of 19.5mm, so protrude under the chassis. If you don't want to find low profile fans, please ensure that you have printed feet for your Simple and installed prior to installing these fan mounts. I use these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:506959 There are two types of mounts included here - the ones in the pictures - these are plain, and contain two mounting points for 60mm fans (central, and towards one end to focus on the stepper drivers in my case). The second design is identical except it contains vents, which reduced the amount of plastic required, and may give better airflow depending on your fans design. My suggestion would be to go with the vented option (version 1.1) first off. As mentioned above, the mounts are designed to friction fit within the chassis, once the fan has been mounted. A dab of hot glue maybe required at each end if you get any material retraction. Print off two mounts for each fan to be installed, and ensure that you print them on their sides to avoid any support material requirements.

This is a proposed modification to the Makelangelo Motor and pen mounts for the drawing robot from www.marginallyclever.com The motor has been flipped and the tip exposed to allow you to add a fun image that can be cut out and mounted on the spindle.
The pen mount has been created and modified from a previous version I made that allows you to squeeze the pen by screwing it into the collar, much like a drill. This I am hoping, makes mounting the pen easier. You also need to orient the servo motor vertically therefore the dxf file for a new plate.
I increased the tolerances so I hope that the screw will not fit too snug. If you print this out and try I, please let me know if it works. I don't have a 3D printer and don't have any cash for Shapeways right now.
This is made to fit with a pen about 13 mm in diameter. A sharpy is 10.5 mm.

title: Panda
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here is Panda! Our fox print seemed to be very well received, so we thought we would do an animals dual extrusion and multicolor series of prints! Panda is the second of this set. Panda is very classic panda with a joyous look on his face. We hope you like him just as much as Fox! If you would like to see a specific animal, please leave a comment for us and we will make it. Check out our website at:
http://www.yourwildworld.com/

For single extruders:  
Download and print out panda1pc.stl We used 2 shells, 10% infill, a raft, and no supports are needed.  
For dual extruders:  
Download and and merge pandawhite.stl and pandablack.stl. Use the same values as above. No support is needed. We merged the two .stl files in Replicator G. We also recommend printing at 210 degrees C to prevent oozing and stringers.

A cheap flex sensor. It is not very precise, but might be useful for some projects. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6lt6fb9za_A&feature=youtu.be

Parts:
  • A piece of PVC tubing 3.5 mm diameter and about 40 mm long
  • Two M4 nuts
  • Two M3x30 screws
  • A graphite pencil
    • Instructions:
    Break the pencil, extract its core and grind it to thin graphite powder with a file. Put M4 nuts at both ends of the PVC tubing. Put an M3 screw from one end, it should fit tightly. Pour graphite powder into the tubing from its other end. Put second screw into place and tighten it. Connect your multimeter and measure sensor resistance. The resistance will probably be around 50 ohms in unbend state. To change this base resistance just tighten or loosen the screws a bit.

description.text:
Replacement part for PRIMO model # 900127 (PRIMO does not have this replacement part on their website, can't find on google either). My sisters water cooler probe broke where the 4 tabs (3 of 4 were broken) on the bottom latch to the unit. All pictures show the original part with the broke tabs and and the newly printed part. Remove the lower disk ring seal and the shaft seal and place on the newly printed probe. New probe was acetone coated for a smoother finish. Layer height: 0.12mm
Infill: 100%
Supports needed: 2mm spacing 1mm away from object in a grid
Print time: 7 hours

So I called Primo directly to see if they could help me get a replacement. They don't show it on their website but if you call their 800 number (which is on the website) and give them the model and serial numbers for your water cooler they can set you up. The part costs $8.99 including shipping, but is currently on back-order with shipping happening middle of June 2017.

description.text:
I made this as a gift for a friend who was really into Portal.  I spent some time over winter holiday putting together the CAD by eye from various images, and when I came back to school I took advantage of the fact that our student machine shop has a 3D printer available for student use to make a few.
SLDPRT file is from Solidworks 2010.
Sentry robot belongs to Valve, I am just borrowing its image for a cool project.

If you have access to a 3D printer and you want to print this you probably don't need my help.  The figure is about 3.5" tall, and to save material I laid it down on its side.  However this means that the front legs are extremely weak and brittle.  I'd recommend either beefing up the slender leg supports or printing it in a different orientation (if one can be found) to make it work better.

comments.author: Gabriel_Carrier

comments.text: DRO_bracket_01.stl is not rigid enough for accurate carriage position indication on my lathe.  Printed in ABS with 50% infill, the DRO has approximately 0.010" backlash.  To be clear, this is the backlash of the digital readout due to friction of the slide causing flexing of this bracket.  Some further development appears to be necessary.
comments.author: abobotek

comments.text: ABS is a flexible plastique, maybe you should try PLA, it is more rigid
comments.author: abobotek

comments.text: Good point - PLA is more rigid, with a Young's modulus in the order of 2x that of ABS.  This would cut the backlash in half (to around 0.005"), but still not be rigid enough to drive the backlash down to the less than the precision of the indicator.  I solved the backlash problem by beefing up the bracket's mounting to the lathe (2 screws near the sides instead of 1 in the middle) and gluing the slide to the upper part of the bracket instead of the lower.

comments.author: jwx23

description.text: I took MiseryBot's fixed 60mmx25mm fan model from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8063 and made it parametric so I could use it for multiple fan sizes. Not for building, just for modeling. The STL file is just for Thingiview to work, you want the SCAD file! I use it in combination with the % operator to help me visualize the end result but not be included in final renderings used for printing.

Include the module with a "use" function at the top of your SCAD file. Create the fan by using the fan module and passing in the width, depth, and mount spacing as parameters in milimeters. I plan to make a set of modules for commonly sized fans to make it easier to use, mostly for the mount spacing because that parameter isn't obvious like the other two are. For now you have to provide the values. There are some other optional parameters to control how rounded the corners are, etc. Look at the source to see them all.

title: Flashforge Creator X/Pro extruder filament tube bracket

description.text:
Yet another press-to-connect (PTC) adapter for the filament guide tubes. Works with commonly available 6mm "Macroline" fittings.  
Fits the Flashforge Creator X and Pro printers (and possibly others that have 34mm nozzle spacing) with the stock 6mm PTFE guide tubes.  
Version 2 adds a support structure for the cable bundle with provisions to install one or two cable ties. The larger cutouts are handy to feed through accessory connectors, as for a filament fan duct.

The holes are tapered to take the 1/8 NPT Macroline thread. Ought to screw right down, with a bit of help from a wrench for the last turn or two.  
The fittings should stay secure even if the last couple of threads are exposed. If you have access one, a quick pass with a 1/8 NPT tap helps to seat the last bit into the tapered hole.

comments.text: Brilliant! I just got my PowerSpec 3D Pro (Flashforge 3D Pro debadged and sold at MicroCenter PC for a lot less).  After my first nozzle clog thanks to some wood filament (which otherwise has been great) I noticed how unreliable and crappy the cable attachment system is on the extruders.   I work professionally performing reliability testing of very similar stepper motor driven mechanisms and I instantly saw how crappy the design is.  A cable will fail on it and with the highly repetitive cycling it will see, an upgrade here is something that should be done for longevity.   I had the thought myself to do something like this as an improvement but it looks like you beat me to it!  Great work, I will print one very soon.

description.text:
Waiting for the electronics to be delivered by mail (IRL mail :) i re-worked some parts to cut on my lasercutter Here is the place i put and update the mendel parts adapted to my laser cutter. Everything is cut in 3mm MDF (maybe 1/8" fits... )
on a 40 Watts epilog zing lasercutter (tuning speed 45%, power 100%)
open the .odg with openoffice 3.2 (seems openoffice3.3 and freeoffice3.3 got some troubles with big printings) I found original plans are in reprap wiki
http://reprap.org/wiki/LaserCut_Mendel
http://www.techzonecom.com/listing.php?cat_id=8 theses no more nedds post-processing, just glue and clamps. Remarks :
I provide .svg i do not tryed, i prefer .odg
I put the pieces here once i tryed them, but nothing can be sure before the first object prints.

instructions are in pictures
Better a drawing than a long speech Here are to build :
  • vertices (needs 6)
  • bar clamp (needs a lot, 12 a minimum plus 2 cross clamp)
  • pcb mount
  • Jig
    • Vertices
  • glue the 6 parts
  • align while gluing the 4 sides, they inserts in strength
  • return and clamp, protect the table with paper
  • once dry, use a small bar to break the walls
    • bar clamps
  • clip the 4 parts of the bar clamp tool
  • insert parts in tool while gluing them
  • return and clamp, protect the table with paper
  • if you put too many glue, remove the tool before completely dry
    • they are really useful little things, i have (and will) glue a lot of them to re-use in other projects. as shown in the picture one M-A-005 + M-A-004 + M-A-004 + M-A-005 made a cross bar clamp Jig
    laser brings precision, it's the perfect tool to cut jigs, this helps a lot for assembly pcb mount
  • two of the small 'u' buils a smal cross, this cross gives centering
    during the gluing of the two identical parts, making a 6mm from 2x3mm
    • TODO_LATER :
  • other parts of mendel...
  • add 9x9 centering cross in vertice to ease assembly
  • bigger or diagonals removable woodwalls
So this is my first design (that isn't hugely structurally unsound).  It is a hollow bead that I designed to be filled to adjust weight for a 3D printed mala.
A simple 2 piece bathroom holder for your razor or toothbrush.
Simple print, no need for supports, once printed the top piece is simple press fitted onto the botoom

remixed_from.title: Coffee Cup Holder and Universal Mount

description.text: My kids wanted to use their Disney mugs for their water in bed, but if they tipped, they leak.  Of course, I saw this as an opportunity to 3D print something.  I found the very nice Coffee Cup holder that in_the_garage made and modified it to suit my purposes.  I put a channel in the side for the handle to slide into and made two screw holes for mounting it.  I printed them in glow in the dark plastic so that they can see them some at night.
Printed with no support and .2mm layers. I used two perimeters and set it to print the inside perimeter first which helped it to print the circle overhangs without drooping.

A pen cap with kendama features. This pendama is very difficult to play. I see it as more of a novelty to look at at this point. However if you are looking for a serious challenge you can make it and try to play. I made this item by injection molding it. There is more information about my injection molding setup here: http://www.scorchworks.com/Injection_molding/injection_molding.html

Model of a "tumor" (irregular solid shape) as a whole object, and divided into 9 slices. The slicing geometry is similar to MRI images, and can be used to estimated the volume of the tumor. This was developed to as a teaching aid for numerical integration.
Three files are included:
"tumor" is the whole object (unsliced).
"tumor1234" is the first four slices arranged to print together.
"tumor56789" is the remaining five slices arranged to print together.
Printed on both Makerbot Replicator and 5th Gen machines, 10% infill with raft.  Supports needed for printing whole tumor.

title: Ergonomic handgripp for Asus Xtion Pro Live

description.text: Ergonomic handgripp for Asus Xtion Pro Live for who, who want to use their Xtion as handheld 3D-Scaner. Made of 2 Half-Parts and 2 Pins to stick them together.

I made the Gripp of Black ABS. Printed with a layer high of 0,15mm. First try was worse because of immense warping of ABS.
Second I try with a 2 Layer thick 15mm raft to work against the warping and it has done very well.

comments.text: This fits the Primesense 1.09 scanner perfectly as well.
comments.author: ICEPICKTONY

comments.text: I have been looking into getting one of these to some 3d scans. have you played with 'reconstructme' using it? if so,. how is the resolution. I love the handle you made. I am sure it will be put on mine if I go this route.
comments.author: ICEPICKTONY

comments.text: No, I have not workd with "ReconstructMe". I use Scenect from Faro its free and has no scansize-limit (I scan whole buildings with this little scanner) the resolution is pretty good (+-5mm at a distance of 3m) but it is a lot of work to make a polygon-model out of the pointcloud. I m using meshlab for it.
comments.author: ICEPICKTONY

comments.text: Thank you. I went with Scanect as well. It supports using a cpu for the reconstruction. Though my PC has a decent GPU, my MS Surface Pro does not. By using Scanect, I am able to do fully portable scans using the tablet, which is something that was not possible using Reconstructme. I am still working on the learning curve thing with Meshlab.

title: Hovership MHQ Beverage Can Landing Gear

description.text: UNTESTED!  I'm not sure if the hovership MHQ can safely/effectively haul a can through the air... but wouldn't it be great if?  Next time I have a crash and need to replace my landing gear, I'm going to replace it with this custom version that is perfectly sized to carry a beverage can of your choice.  Let me know if you print and fly successfully, and party on.
ABS w/ 10% infill to keep the weight down, seems strong enough.

comments.text: hilarious idea! Im running 6x4.5 props, and with the insane g/w ratio of the hovership motors, I bet it could work! 1 motor alone has enough thrust at 100% to lift my quad... that leaves a solid 1500ish grams free! Do note though... you DON'T want to be near 100% throttle if your ESCs have a low max burst and time... Hopefully a small can of bear/soda wouldnt bring you too close, BUT adding this much weight and trying to fly for more than tenish seconds could be risky...either way, love the idea, may have to try out!
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text: After a few crashes I rebuilt mine as an MHQ2 so the landing gear is now a bit more spread out.  It could fit a tall-boy, but so much more weight I dunno.  A normal can of beer is like 325g or something to that effect, about twice as much as an 1800mah lipo.  I bet with a small battery you could totally get airborne.
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text: Due to the weight+unstability of having a beer can on I would remove your FPV setup to try it and just fly LOS. My MHQ2 weighs around 590, which is around the thrust of the hovership 2300kv motors with 6x4.5 props. With 6x4.5 props I can lift my MHQ2 at around 54% throttle however I am not sure if it is safe to fly at full throttle with these props as I worry it may burn out the ESCs. I fly with a kk2.1.5 board, a 1400mah battery and a gopro and hoverships motors and escs. With 6x4.5s I get around 9 minutes of non strenuous flying. To reduce weight you could remove gopro and have a smaller battery, but wouldnt as my settings are tuned to balance gopro and battery. I bet it could still lift it then, it would probably just take a lot more throttle. See this link for more info about thrust and stuff: http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2200344

author: Tiladawn

description.text:
8/29/2017 UPDATE: All I can say is WOW! I haven't logged into thingiverse in such a long time, and I am genuinely surprised how much attention this design is still getting!
I graduated from college, got a job, moved out, and gone through some life changes, took a hiatus from "making", and now I am back!
I plan on reviving this project from the fiery depths of my project bucket, and finally getting something that is easily obtainable for all! I hereby announce the beginning design phases of a printable mechanical counter compatible with this design! More updates to come!

I designed a filament counter to display the number of meters of filament used. (it displays the 1/10'ths place, hence the white-out decimal point)
It utilizes the core of a Veeder-Root 742946-201 non-resetable rotary counter.
I doubt you would be able to find another one of these out there in the wild, and the nearest sibling costs $100+, so I will work on a printable counter eventually. Maybe someone else will get to it before me, who knows.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/DANAHER-VEEDER-ROOT-0742845-001-MECHANICAL-RESET-COUNTER-5-DIGIT-XLNT-/150854138839?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item231f9b7bd7 #########################################################
#########################################################
I AM WORKING ON A VERSION 2
that utilizes a $4 electromechanical counter available on ebay, and utilizes a 5v pulse signal. The counter is en-route to me from china, so it might take a bit to get working on it.
#########################################################
######################################################### If you happen to have a compatible counter, great!
You need 1 of each part.
The orientation might be weird when importing the STL files, but just use your head.
I designed the "baseplate" in such a way that it could be mounted easily to other printers with the design of a custom mounting bracket.
This one comes with a simple zip-tie bracket for the aluminum handle of a Printrbot simple metal This requires some rubber bands, bolts, and hole reaming to finish. I used 1/4 inch shoulder bolts that I had lying around.
You also need to cut and glue a rubber band around the counter gear. Mine has been silently counting along flawlessly since I first printed it! EDIT: I accidentally uploaded a .slprt file instead of the STL. I renamed the counter wheel and the counter output shaft gear to be less ambiguous.

author: RepRapWarehouse

description.text: Spinner bait skirt. I made this skirt from extruded silicone caulk but it may be a good candidate fro ninjaflex or similar material. I did catch a larger fish (32 inch Northern Pike) with one of these skirts but I didn't have a camera along for that trip. More information about my silicone caulk extruder setup is available here: http://www.scorchworks.com/3Dprinting/3dprinting.html

I love my Prusa i3V but the stock spool holder leaves much to be desired. It obstructs the access to the SD card, it makes strange noises with some spools replacing spools is a hassle due to the design of its cross member and its height makes it more difficult to cover it with a box to control draft. Clearly a better design is required.  
This thing moves the spool from the top of the printer to its left side just behind the z step motor. It is made of three parts, the spool holder, the filament guide and a round spacer that matches the stock M5 screw that comes with the Prusa i3V.   
The shiny cylinder part of the filament guide is a short stainless still I found in a local hardware store (The Hillman Group 1/4-in x 3/8-in x 1-in, Seamless Steel Spacer model 880416). It is hold in place with two M3 screws from both side. The cylinder can turns but it's not critical as long as it is smooth.  I also wrapped kapton tape on the main spool holder to reduce friction, probably not required but doesn't hurt.  
The main part is held in place with 4 M3 screws. Use small washers on the plastic side (they will sink into the base) and large ones on the wood side. Make sure to position it such it can accomodate all the spool sizes you intend to use without touching the Z step motor (remember, the Z step motor moves up and down and should have enough clearance in all positions).   
Printing is straight forward I printed everything with PLA and no material support.   
All sources files are included so if you need to tweak it modify the relevant file and regenerate the STL files in openscad. My printer has 8" x 8" hotbed but I think it should work with all i3V versions.

An exposed double edged razor blade lying flat can be dangerous to try to pick up, especially in a medical environment where they may be contaminated. I designed this thing to easily pick up and release them; it may come in handy in other situations, too. The lifter consists of a piston with a small magnet on one end. With the cap all the way down, the magnet butts up to the edge of the cylinder. When the cap is lifted, the magnet retracts away from the end, releasing the blade. Update: v2 modifications for one handed use.
To avoid contaminating the lifter itself, you could place part of a latex glove or plastic bag over the tip. Update: v2 ring was a little fragile, cap-v3 beefs it up.

Print the three parts with flat faces down. The piston goes in the cylinder, and the cap is glued onto the end of the end rod. There is a circular indentation on the cap to aid in alignment. A 1/8" x 1/16" (nominal: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0065O63BK) neodymium magnet gets glued into the hole on the end of the piston.

comments.text: suggestion modification for one handed use; a thumb ring on the cap and two coves cut in the cylinder so that it can be operated like a syringe if needed.

title: Obi-Wan Kenobi "Complex" Lightsaber Modified Pin and Lightbulbs (original by Ultimaker)

description.text: I've modified a couple bits of the "complex" Obiwan lightsaber because they didn't print great for me.  Thanks to Ultimaker/Jacky/Valcros for the original awesome files!!!  More info on Instructions tab.

I've modified a couple bits of the "complex" Obiwan lightsaber because they didn't print great for me. Find the original files and license in the “Original Obiwan Lightsaber Complex” folder. Thanks to Ultimaker for the awesome files!!! I printed everything at “High” on a Flashforge clone of the original Replicator Dual in ABS, except the D-Ring jig. I used a raft, but no supports as the original was designed to print well without supports. I batched several of the components together, and it took about 24 hours of printing for everything, plus a tiny bit more for my modified parts. I changed 2 things: • Lightbulbs Flat - I printed the “lightbulbs” in translucent clear ABS and they drooped in the vertical orientation (but looked fine in gray). So I removed the support and oriented them flat on their back. I assume Ultimaker had trouble with the flat position (otherwise why make the fancy support?) but flat worked better for me. You may want to try both. • Pin with supports in 3 lengths – I couldn’t get the pin to print at all, and it seemed to be a smidgen too short. I added some supports and it prints fine this way (on a raft, don’t select supports in the slicer), trim off the supports when done. Worked great. I’m using the 22mm pin, though it might be a hair too long. (Original was 20mm, I’m guessing I’m shrinking more than Ultimaker or something). You can just stretch the pin before printing if you want it a 1/2mm bigger or smaller or whatever. Most everything fit well after cleaning the parts, though I trimmed the buttons inside so that the grenade and pommel parts fit correctly. I had trouble getting the lever/switch to attach to the pin, so I trimmed it by hand a little. It doesn’t seem like it “works” as a lever and so I intend to glue it on. Ultimaker apparently said the original intent of the DRING Jig part is to bend a heated piece of filament to make a D-Ring shape. Seems reasonable, but I think I might want to use a D-Ring if it was there. If I do a d-ring, I’ll probably just buy a metal one from the hardware store, so I didn’t try the D-Ring jig. Props to Ultimaker/Jacky/Valcrow for the original plans: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/star-wars-lightsaber-complex-version - Make sure you visit their page there, they have links to blogs & stuff. Seems kinda strange to put an Ultimaker project on Thingiverse, but it is CC. I did want to share the modified parts, I don't have an account there, and I get frustrated when I see helpful modifications with the rest of the parts for the project. Consider it a social experiment.

description.text:
The accordeon-like cover prevents dust from getting inside my UMO. BOM:
2x AccordeonMount.STL for attachement to the sliders
2x printed beams consisting of AccordeonBar_xy_a.STL & AccordeonBar_xy_b.STL
2x printed cover frame (2x cover_RHLV.stl / 2x cover_RVLH.stl)
4x printed connectors (joiner.STL)
1x printhead cover from thingiverse link
1x IKEA Schottis (http://www.ikea.com/at/de/catalog/products/20242282/)
double sided tape and cyanoacylate for assambling Assambly:
  • print all parts in the required quantity
  • download print head cover (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77120) and print it also if you don´t have it already
  • cut IKEA-IKEA Schottis to lenght for x and y axis
  • assamble slider consisting of accordeon mount and accordeon beams a and b
    ﻿IMPORTANT: one side should be open to be able to slide the bowden through.﻿
  • use double sided tape to attache the shorted Schottis to the accordeon beams
  • connect the front and rear cover parts using the connetors and some cyanoacrylat glue. IMPORTANT: one side should be open to be able to slide the bowden through.
  • use double sided tape to attache the shorted Schottis to the front and rear covers
  • slip over the bowden and mount it onto the UMO

title: Mini Kossel Frame Brace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
FYI: A lot of you want this brace for 2020 extrusion but I don't have any at home to model it on and more importantly I need to measure the carriage height when the nozzle is at Z0 and X,Z at the maximum width (this will give me the lowest point a carriage go down). If you are willing to reply in the comment or send me a pm with the measurement below I will adapt the brace to fit 2020
  • The maximum build volume in mm
  • The height of the y or z carriage when effector is homed in front of the tower
  • A link to motor bracket using 2020
  • 2020 extrusion use M4 screw right?
    • The kossel design is great but the high tower and 15mm extrusion mean there is a bit of twisting occurring within the tower (to check this just grab 2 of the 3 tower and twist in clockwise or counter clockwise and you'll notice it), it can lead to tower twisting when tightening up the belt to reduce that effect I've designed this small brace. They can be fitted once your kossel is already assembled however I will recommend that you untight the top part of the frame and remove tension from the belt fit the brace and put back the tension and redo manual calibration. Share the love and submit a made on :-)

Print those with the same setting as you will for kossel parts. I've print mine at 0.3 layer height with 3 shells and 40% infill. Anything lower IMHO and there is not even a point of printing those.   
NOTE: If you use "framebrace_v1" it might slightly reduce the build platform diameter. For me I use 40x40x20 fan and this mean that the fan slightly touch the brace when printing an object with maximum diameter than I need to take this into consideration and alter the wipe in my start gcode. Check freedom of movement the first time you use the printer with those installed but V1 is much stronger than V2.

comments.text: Sorry this was done in Tinkercad a while back sharing the original won't help much as it just a bundle of shape. But assuming that the size percentage increase between a 15x15 and a 20x20 is around 33.3...% scaling up that brace to 133 percent in your slicer should work just fine. To test this just print the bottom 1 to 2 mm of the brace and stop the print check if it fit your extrusion and voila :-) I don't have 20x20 extrusion to test but in my slicer scaling the brace to 132.5% seems to work. Finally you might have to rim the screw hole with a drill bit. Hope this help :-) PS: if you build a bigger delta try to scale the brace in the height to 150% as it will increase/improve the stability too

author: Ksstyling

description.text:
A hard case designed to fit the Samsung Galaxy S5.
I designed this base for creating designer cases for a Samsung Galaxy S5 phone. I print my cases at 0.1 mm layer, Shell thickness 0.8, Bottom/ Top thickness 0.8 mm, With Supports, (ABS or PLA)
Design samples that I have created using this model as the base are also supplied. Updates:
04/02/2014 - Shifted the locations of the power and volume button slots so they should be more centered on the buttons. Made the depth of the case a little shorter (i.e. from 11 mm to 10.95 mm). A Test print stl also included so that you can check the fit without wasting too much material. All Older .stl files can be found in the zip archive. 17/01/2014 - Uploaded two additional cases based on the base case. These two are also plain and hex patterned with the sides, top and bottom exposed for those who desire a minimalist type case. Giving total access to the power and volume buttons as well as removing the top edge that may interfere with user's ability to swipe. 14/06/2016 - A few folks have been asking me for the CAD file for this case. So I have uploaded it for those who prefer the CAD file over the .stl for their own modifications. It is an inventor file (.ipt) 15/01/2017 - Uploaded s5 rev4-3_bumper.stl as requested
My cases I print at 0.1 mm layer, Shell thickness 0.8, Bottom/ Top thickness 0.8 mm. Default infill (20%) or you can increase as you desire. I use supports for the on/off/ volume button slots.

comments.text:
Hi, Can you give a little more details such as which case and the dimensions that shows up in your slicer? The dimensions of these cases (as measured in netfabb) are length: 144mm, width: 77mm and height:11mm. These were the dimensions that fit on my Samsung Galaxy S5 (Verizon) when printed in both ABS and PLA.
Any smaller and I thought that it would squeeze my phone too much and made it difficult to put on. This case of course, will not work for flexible PLA as it was designed for a harder material.
You can try scaling the axis in question if you think that you need it shorter.
comments.author: Eedh

comments.text: Hi, I've printed the hexa-case with ABS material. The phone fits inside but the sidewalls or the edges which are overhanging are so high that I can not touch the outer areas anymore. So can not use SwipePad for example. I'm actually about to design my own case.
comments.author: umqais

comments.text: Ah ok, I think I understand what you want (which does not mean that the phone does not fit properly, cause I did re-print it last night and phones do fit ). I guess in your case you desire the edges of the top outer surface edge (i.e. the lip) chamfered a bit to slope down to meet flush with the edge of the screen (i.e. reducing the thickness of the case at that edge). That will weaken the case in that area though, making the shell easier to crack as you will be reducing the width/ thickness. I can alternatively shorten the width of that lip but that will also weaken the case in that direction and it might not hold the case shell on the phone properly. I am thinking that It might be better to just cut away the sides for those who don't want to that lip and keep four corners (which I am going to do) and provide those alternate files as well. For me personally, I prefer that extra protection of the screen as it does not affect my ability to swipe... but I  do understand for some, they want to feel a flush face with no ridge.
comments.author: Eedh

title: End Stop to Power off printer

description.text:
I use Octoprint to make my Rapide Lite 200 wireless. But i need a way to shutdown my printer when not at home. I created a End Stop holder and bought a End Stop switch and placed it to the side of my Rapide Lite. I bought this: http://bit.ly/145eNPy
Its a microswitch connected through COM and NC. This means, that when the switch is made it cuts the power through the circuit. When i run my X-axis to the max distance of the print bed (~195 mm from the home position) the switches wheel hits the side of the platform on which the printbed is placed - and the switch cuts the power to the printer. Since my printer uses Marlin, i havent found a way to use any gcode commands to shut it down. I saw that you can use the M81-command to shut it down, but that didnt work on my printer - so i had to create this. EDIT: You can do this by wiring the RAMPS board. I didnt know this at the time of this creation - but heres a link for you:
https://github.com/foosel/OctoPrint/wiki/Control-your-printer's-ATX-PSU-through-a-RAMPS-board-using-OctoPrint You can customize this in Tinkercad:
https://tinkercad.com/things/fq7VjVG7AkO-power-end-stop

title: Double Hinged 12864 Full Graphics LCD Frame

description.text: This is a follow-up on my previous project Double Hinged Smart 2004 LCD Frame, this time for the RepRapDiscount Full Graphics 12864 LCD Controller. The LCD frame is mounted on my box frame Prusa i3 via the same sturdy double hinge mechanism, so that the display can be folded away when not it use. For further details, photos and instructions regarding the spring loaded hinge mechanism please refer to the LCD2004 version. There you also find the mirrored version of the hinge mechanism, in case that one fits better your specific needs. The fully configured SCAD file is contains the source for both the graphic LCD12864 and the non-graphic LCD2004 versions. Ready-to-print STL files are provided for the LCD frame and for the hinge mechanism. Update 2015-02-21: I just uploaded an additional smaller square version of the hinge. this might be useful for situations where only little space is available for mounting the hinge. Update 2016-12-18: User menerso (thank you!) noted that the small hinge was not able to rotate correctly without rasping away part of a corner of one of the pieces. So I replaced the corresponding STL file with the corresponding version from my TinyOLED controller which does not have this problem.

description.text:
We conducted a very quick test temperature resistance (70 °) for 3 3D printing materials we use regularly. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pjc7gnhaChQ
  • PLA (polylactic acid)
  • PET (polyethylene terephthalate)
  • Nylon
    • We performed this test with the same file and the same 3D print setting (filling 100%). Each object is 5mm thick, 15mm height and 40 mm in length. PLA at a temperature of 70 ° becomes very resilient and the deformation is irreversible.
    PET at a temperature of 70 ° resists perfectly.
    Nylon at a temperature of 70 ° it also resists perfectly. Conclusion: Choosing your 3D printing materials and very important. PLA for use in your home or office can meet your need perfectly. But never let PLA near a heat box or in your car in the summer. We will soon test with ABS and Polycarbonate.

remixed_from.author: berryd
remixed_from.title: Airtripper Bowden Copy For MK7 Hobbed Shaft Collar

description.text: Squirrels love a nut.  Airtrippers suck with a nut.  I've never had mine pop off, but I have a hell of a time getting in new filament, so I have modified it to accept a threaded adapter for the bowden tube.  This is derived from my other derived airtripper, and from the threaded bowden clamp posted by jamesarm97.  This is not parametric, so if it doesn't fit for you, bust out the files or sandpaper.

Print, assemble.  The raised squares should line up.  I considered adding a snap on the extruder housing against the adapter, but I don't think keeping it in place will be a concern.  Fair warning:  I haven't tried this yet.  It might still need adjusting.  I've printed two, and the pieces fit nice and snug, but my printer and I aren't getting along at the moment and she is making weak parts.  
The hotend adapter should accomodate a Jhead....  You might need to tweak the scale on the ring or cap.

description.text: Cradle for the Full Graphic Smart Controller case at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213852 All the mounts I could find were for permanently mounting the controller case to the frame but I wanted to be able to easily remove the controller. With this solution the cradle is fastened to the frame but you can lift the controller out of the cradle when needed. This was designed for the Prusa i3 Rework from Replikeo but it will probably work with similar printers that have a 3mm frame thickness as the two pieces of the cradle just clamp over the top of the frame. Sliced with Slic3r. Layer height 0.2mm, 30% honeycomb infill and 3mm brim. Left bracket should be printed with support material ON. Use two M3 nuts and bolts to fasten pieces to top of frame. The circular cutout in the right piece is designed to fit the knob included with the case linked above.

description.text: This is the easiest way I've found to mount my GoPro camera to just about anything, or at least anything you can get a hose clamp around.  There's two versions, one in which the clamp axis is parallel to whatever you're clamping to and one in which the axis is perpendicular.

These mounts are made to work with 1/2" wide hose clamps, the run-of-the-mill hose clamps you can buy at any hardware store.  To keep the mounts from sliding around whatever you're clamping them to, it helps to put a piece of rubber inside the hose clamp.  I find that a cheap pack of vacuum cleaner drive-belts fits the bill perfectly.

title: Clip-on Printrbot brushless blower turbine fan mount

description.text:
This is a clip-on mount for attaching a brushless blower fan to a Printrbot+ extruder. Assuming the extruder dimensions are constant, this will likely work for all Printrbots with laser-cut wooden extruders.  
It was designed to work with a 5015S blower fan purchased from eBay for $4.89, which is 50mmx15mm high, runs at 3800rpm, and puts out 20CFM. It runs circles around the 40mm PC fans I'd tried previously to use to cool filament.
In the photo, it looks as though the bottom edge of the blower is lower than the tip of the extruder nozzle, but that's due to the angle at which the photo was taken. The bottom edge of the fan housing is at least 1mm higher than the end of the nozzle, which is plenty.

Here are the more interesting settings I used, which worked fine: .35mm extruder nozzle
3mm black PLA plastic Slic3r settings:
overhang threshold: 60Âº
Pattern: honeycomb
Pattern spacing: 40mm
Pattern angle: 0Âº infill:
Fill density: .1
Fill pattern: rectilinear
Top/bottom fill pattern: concentric
Infill every: 2 layers
Fill angle: 45Âº I printed using Repetier-Host Mac 0.53, and had to rotate the object 90Âº on its X axis in order to place it flat on the print bed. This mount takes inspiration from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29565, but aims to be more minimal. I designed the mount such that it holds itself in place using friction and also has little arms that poke through holes in the sides of the extruder platform and extend to its back to provide even more support for the weight of the fan. If you print this in PLA, the object may be too brittle to bend enough to fit both arms into the holes, and one may snap. This happened to me, and I just glued it together in-place using a drop of cyanoacrylate. It'll likely hold in place without those arms, but they provide just a little more support. This is my first attempt at a semi-complicated CAD project, and I expect many of you who might benefit from such a mount can probably improve upon this design and make a nice derivative. So in addition to the printable STL file, I've uploaded the original .f3d file (object was designed in Autodesk Inventor Fusion), and an exported STP file. Here's the link to the blower fan I'm using:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/1-PCS-12V-DC-50MM-x-15MM-Turbine-Brushless-Cooling-Blower-Fan-5015S-12V-0-1A-/221041441726?ssPageName=ADME:L:OU:US:3160

comments.text: I got tired of propping this print in place and watching it droop due to the fact that I printed it in PLA and it's close to the hot extruder. So I've replaced it with a bent piece of metal cut from a tin of anchovies into which I'd drilled a couple of holes to match up with the extruder mount's screws.

comments.text: It seems when the extruder heats up, it causes the particular plastic with which I printed to expand, and the friction doesn't hold, and the mount dips. Nothing a bent bobby pin can't hold in place for now, but I'll be revising this design at some point so that the solution looks better.

  • Download the STL of the file you would like to print. The first thumbnail corresponds to portrait_1, and so on.
  • Open the STL in MakerWare or ReplicatorG, resize as necessary and print.

Custom cookier designed by ms_harrison using CookieCaster: http://www.cookiecaster.com Dimensions:
Longest Length: ~4.0 inches (10.2 cm)
Height: 0.65 inches (1.7 cm)
Thickness: 0.08 inches (2.0 mm)\n ( change dimensions at: http://cookiecaster.com/casts/8783 )

CookieCaster cookie cutters are easily printed on your MakerBot using the standard settings - we recommend using PLA to print and then saran wrap for cutting to make cleanup easy and to prevent any loose plastic from getting in your cookies
